When I was in Delhi earlier this year, I had lunch with well-known Indian publisher Dina Malhotra, who gave me a copy of his book, Dare to Publish. Mr. Malhotra pioneered the paper book revolution in India, and made inexpensively produced books available to the masses. He visited train platform book stalls for orders, started book clubs across the country and did much to bring reading to the literate poor.

These publishers are doing the same thing. They are bringing books to readers who might otherwise feel disenfranchised.

It is normal and natural for people to want art and entertainment that speaks to them, at their level of understanding and about their situations and experiences. Even Shakespeare wrote for the masses of people who paid almost nothing to sit on the ground in front of the stage. His plays were popular because they appealed to everyone at every level of education and society. Hindi masala movies from "Bollywood" are the same.

I might not want to read these books, but that doesn't mean they shouldn't be published. Personally, I think it's an exciting development -- part of the bigger picture of India coming into its own in the 21st century. Which, for my money, is one of the most fascinating stories on the planet right now,

The "narrative" is the problem. It's a rhetorical device used by journalists that is inherently biased: a great example of this is Nicholas Kristof, whose writing on India is based on simplistic stereotypes, bad journalism, and frankly is racist at times. When it fits with the stereotypes of some audience members (particularly in the UK, or special interest groups with an axe to grind) it's praised as nuanced and balanced (which it isn't). However, he simply cherry picks experiences that fit with his own world view, simplistic binaries, and attempts to reassess AIDS, TB, and malnutrition rates for the entire country by simply visiting a few villages.

How can someone write *more* accurately about India? By adopting a more scientific approach to literature. Look at statistics for malnutrition and economic development, and see if your interviews broadly reflect that trend. Kerala has a literacy rate of > 90%. If you've interviewed 5 people you cherry picked and they're all illiterate, chances are there was a selection bias in your method. This is what separates a writer from a scientist: reproducible methodology. Randomly quoting statistics without looking at construct validity is another issue: you might find an article on the Internet that claims that India's literacy rate is 62%. However, this would be incorrect: the UN/Unicef/Indian census puts it at about 75%. Being exhaustive, systematic, and redundant (ie. find multiple sources to corroborate a finding) is important.

Also, have an eye for nuance. While pandering to stereotypes a la Mr. Kristof might sell well with a particular demographic, it's fundamentally bad writing and bad journalism.

In summary: don't construct a "narrative." Present comprehensive, nuanced, corroborated facts that allow for diversity. You can offer your interpretation at the end of a book, but don't let your "opinion" drive it. Or else you'll end up writing something bad, cliched, racist, and most importantly, wrong.

Just my thoughts.

Back in early 1970s at a university dorms, about 60 miles west behind the Iron Curtain, my roommate and by far the smartest student among all of us has been frequently visited by Witnesses.

Their calculations of the for-sure End (1977?) were supposedly convincing. After all, they - not the 'prostitute' (the Rome) - were the true students and interpreters of the Bible.

Ever since, when I see them behind the door of my house here ... or at metro stops back in my birthplace, solemnly distributing the WatchTower, I have to smile at their conviction, determination, and devotion. Sometimes I ask them how they know that there will not be another "End is coming in 1977" fiasco. They answer me, almost uniformly, that that was a 'human error'. For some reason it sounds to me like when communists 'explain' bloody totality of communism everywhere when it has been tried: The teaching/ideology/Marx is fine, but the implementation, people failed.

Yes, tax breaks for religious organisations (and many 'non-profits'?) should be looked into. They do not help our global competitiveness and that seem to be, not only in never-ending era of budget deficits but also in merciless competition from the rest of the world which too often can outdo us and outproduce us, we can less afford a generosity of the times when lived in a world of our own or reaped huge benefits from having the monopoly on printing the world's reserve currency. It is the same thing like giving taxpayers' subsidies to an undergraduate student majoring say in Italian Literature. Nice, if one can pay for it, but not worthy taxpayer subsidy (of such student or faculty teaching that at our educational-industrial complex.)

@HKGuy (#2): The price drop reflects the gut renovation that was begun, but not completed (as mentioned), and of course, the vagaries of the ultra-high-end market. My guess is the interior doesn't "show well" anymore, to say the least.

Also, absurd as it may seem, your renovation figure is off by a factor of 4-7x or more. The mansion is over 21,000 s.f., so $3 million would be roughly $150/s.f. (My understanding is that the gutting alone ran about $4 million, though that may have included the cleaning of the exterior limestone facade.) I work with a number of architects that specialize in high-end residential - my wife is one - and I can tell you an appropriate remodel of a top-of-the-market place like this, with finishes and craftsmanship commensurate to both status of the building itself and the tastes of a buyer able to afford it, would run $500/s.f. *minimum*, and could easily top $1000/s.f., depending on the details. Obviously, that works out to $11-22 million+, or, essentially, the difference in selling prices.

Like it or not, the rich really are different from you and me.

It's such a sad commentary on our community life today. I grew up with educated, accomplished people being admired and aspired to. One foreman I worked with told me to use my head, not my muscle to get ahead. (And he was no slouch in the intelligence department)

But today, after 40 plus years of scorn heaped upon teachers, their unions, educated people and just those who like to think, we are slipping over the edge in destroying our society. Republicans complain about bureaucrats, but studies in many third-world nations, find business and industry begin to thrive with bureaucrats begin to grow in numbers. They keep track of inventory and budgets and production schedules. They notice when the numbers are off and help fix the problems.

But now, it's a race back to the 18th century (if we're lucky). Those "golden days" are praised for their non-governmental interference and the "freedom" poor people had to die in great numbers under conditions not of their own making.

Our national motto seems to be "Hey, I'm with Stupid" with an arrow pointing to the Right.

Maybe Perry's just the guy to lead us into the next phase of the American experience. We're becoming a banana republic, and we'll need the kind of jobs Perry is so proud of having created in Texas: low-skilled, low-paying service jobs that come without benefits. Wealthy corporations will sell our cheaply made products to countries that are on the way up, like China. If we had any book larnin', we'd probably recognize the irony in that turn of events.

As we awaken from our American Dream, in which every generation did better than the last, we'll need someone to march us through the dark valley of Lowered Expectations. Who better to do that than a D student who knows the landscape? There are times when an education, compassion, and a sense of hope are serious disadvantages. We're entering one of those times, and it's comforting to know there are Republicans like Rick Perry to lead the way.

We better learn to accept it. This D and F student Perry is almost certain to become the next president of the United States. In the meantime you look at the resume of the leaders of our competitors in the world and it is no wonder that the U.S. Is receding fast on the world stage. Look at the intellectualism of the Chinese leader for example and of most of the European leaders. I understand that in China most of their congressmen equivalents are engineers and business leaders. Most Asian leaders are also intellectual superstars. It is a shame people have not made the connection between when we hired our last D student for president (George Bush) and the state of the economy. Well I still wish the best for this great country and hopefully our current anti intellectualism will only be a temporary blip in our history.

Last night on “Charlie Rose,” I listened to Lisa Randall, the first woman tenured in physics by Princeton and Harvard, discuss her new book, “Knocking On Heaven’s Door”, an attempt to explain the importance of science and cutting edge ideas in physics to a lay audience. Born in Queens and a graduate of Stuyvesant High (note to out-of-towners: Stuyvesant is the elite NYC public high school for brilliant math and science students), Randall is going to win the Nobel Prize someday for her work in particle physics and, in particular, her theories regarding multi-dimensional space.

I was enthralled, as usual, by Randall, who is consumed with curiosity about science, the universe and just – life. She’s inspiring; not because she preaches sermons, but due to her genius and clarity. She actually makes particle physics clear to a lay audience.

Randall’s writings are an attempt to convince the public that science, and scientific thinking, are important. Unfortunately, not only will most of the Perry supporters not read her book, but they do not even have the basic concepts in math and science – high school stuff – required to understand it. Watching Randall, I wanted to cry. She is everything that America should be, everything we should strive to be (I acknowledge that my first love was astronomy and I have always been sad that I’m just not smart enough to be a physicist) – and everything that we should want for our kids.

Instead we are embracing stupidity; and it shows. We may still product Lisa Randalls, but we are no longer a country that recognizes what Lisa Randalls are for.

I understand that people have a different political perspective than I do.  Intellectually I get that conservatives have one perspective on abortion, gun control, climate change and the death penalty and I have another.  What I don't get is how the electorate is so readily embracing stupidity.  The leader of the free world should be the smartest guy or gal in the room.  Not the dumbest.  As a teacher, I am so unsettled by the elevation of the candidacies of Rick Perry and Michelle Bachmann.  Both are entitled to their opinions, but the promotion of their ignorance and duplicity is appalling.  I work in an independent school where parents pay thousands of dollars to obtain an education for their children. My parents--one an immigrant, the other someone who left high school (but earned her diploma) to work--worked hard to ensure that my sister and I would be educated.  The Republicans have campaigned against education, deriding it as elitist and denigrating science.  Why would we as a country want to be dumbed down?  Is this part of some weird kind of conspiracy?  Is the lack of intelligence on the part of the electorate the only way the Republicans can continue to win elections?

Touche.

But you missed big time on the “'God uses broken people to reach a broken world'" part. Perry does, I think, refer to a respectable spiritual concept. It "even means," as I understand it, that we are all vessels containing a spark of the divine, and when that vessel is broken, that spark of divinity becomes more available to others. When the world is struggling, making divinity more easily available to others is helpful, like breaking up food into small pieces for an invalid. Henri Nouwen wrote on this theme a lot, and is far more cogent than I am on it. And Father Nouwen was, in this taxonomy, on the Egghead team, I think, having taught at Harvard and Yale; but he would have been happy to break bread with members of the Blockhead team, too. So, Gov. Perry's statement seems to me to undermine, rather than support, your thesis. But I enjoyed the column thoroughly nonetheless.

Since he's the new kid on the stage, I thought you might appreciate this anecdote. I was in Austin, Texas in early December and went with my daughter to a movie at a triplex in a little strip mall. When we left the theatre, we encountered five brand new, shiny, black Escalade SUV's lined up outside, each with at least a couple of guys in dark suits standing by, wearing wrap around shades (it was evening), and little wires snaking out behind their right ears. I went up to one of them and asked what was going on, and he said "Governer Perry is at the movie".

This from a governor who hates government and lives in a state where the legislature meets once every two years for 150 days, maximum, and the lieutenant governor is actually the person who approves all budgets and does all the heavy lifting.

God help us.
